author: MoesBAR
body:
Full disclosure: these were tiny bets for fun on dirt cheap stocks in April, so short of them going out of business I knew they’d make a return.

Now most stuff is kinda overpriced so I’m just holding on to my original investments from earlier this year.

Only things I’ve bought somewhat recently are Western Digital & Seagate because I think they have great potential to sell a lot of SSD storage for the next gen of consoles and PC gamers. I got in on AMD at $55 cause they’re making the chips for PS5 and Xbox X.

I’ll trade some Roku stock here and there because they range from 140s to 170s.

Maybe I buy a little of recovery stocks that are hit really hard now or on downward days but that should recover like Coty which is at $3 and they’re a big makeup company that should do better when woman aren’t all wearing masks outside.

AGS makes gaming machines for casinos, they’re at $4, if they hit $3.8 or less that’s a buying opportunity cause they usually go back up to $4.4 and if they survive to post Covid they might be $10+ stock again.

I’m not an expert so please do your research and always diversify.

author: marilius12
body:
The price of a stock alone says nothing about it being cheap or expensive. You need to also consider the number of shares outstanding. That's why instead of looking at the stock quote you should look at ratios like P/E.

So, what you're asking is what are some value stocks with relatively low P/Es compared to the S&P average for example. There are several sectors that are "cheap" - these are your banks like JPM and BAC, manufacturers like MMM and HON, even some tech like INTC, CSCO, and STX.

Note that low P/E are often indicative of low growth expectations. So you are trading stability (low beta) and dividends for capital appreciation.

author: Endda
body:
I like STX for the dividend so it's definitely not in my portfolio as a growth play.

That said, I do agree that they need to pivot in some way. Even Western Digital has them on the tech front.

It doesn't even feel like they've capitalized on WD's recent issues as much as they could have. So yea, unless the price drops a ton, I'll keep what I have in the company for its dividend. But I'm not expecting it to go to the moon anytime soon.

author: thetimsterr
body: I think is this a great point and one that is possibly not being considered by the market. The demand for cloud storage is going to skyrocket in the next 5 years (more than it already has). Seems like Seagate is well-positioned to fill that demand, moreso than WDC or Toshiba.

author: LifeTaylor
body:
19% of my portfolio is in Intel.  I bought in at $48.61  

I may sell it off at some point, but its more a long-term play. Currently I think AMD (and Nvidia) are massively inflated even if they are the leaders currently and I also have stakes in them as well.

My logic may be skewed, but you know schools are giving every student a laptop..   Each one of these laptops have intel integrated graphics, which means I'm sure Intel will do fine over the next year.  Same philosophy with logitech, western digital, and seagate..   millions more computers being distributed, means that top companies that produce hard drives, Ram, CPUs, GPUs, and computer accessories are making some good profits. Not to mention gaming during a pandemic is at an all time high.

author: snake250
body:
Right yeah, the 5% dividend yield in a ZIRP environment is indicative of the market's expectation that it will not be sustained (but their payout ratio is below 60% so I'm not worried about that).

However, my thesis is that Seagate don't need to pivot to do better in the future. I am arguing that just the sheer expansion of cloud storage needs will take care of that. If I'm right and the market has overlooked this, then we could be looking at increased future cash flows => dividend increases.

author: lllkill
body: Anyone know what stocks are good for data storage?  I see seagate but it seems mediocre.

author: further_along
body: PM is great. So is IP and STX for the Div love.

author: bwel99
body:
And that is where I'm going back and forth here. I expect the share price to rise fairly soon. They just merged with STX films, which is a mid-sized hollywood studio (The Gentlemen by Guy Ritchie is from STX). They are supposed to do a big investor presentation and ring the bell at the NYSE in Sept.

So ideally, if it rose to $5 in a month or so, I would want to close out with a good profit.  But if I had to hold to expiry, it wouldn't actually be that much money tied up, since the premium is more than half the share price.

author: MoesBAR
body:
For their volumes I’m sure it’s significant discounts but I think their sales to PC players upgrading their systems will be much healthier margins though I’ve heard Nvidia is also releasing very impressive graphics cards at low cost so would be good to diversify in both. 

I’m also bought into Western Digital and Seagate for external flash memory storage as the spacing needs for next gen games will be huge and those are all after market so should be better margins too. 

Obviously, all of this is long term 2-3 year investments as more and more people upgrade over time.

body:

Reversals (stocks trending up from a recent 52 week/6 month low)

LMFA  CPB

author: Ironleg01
body: HPE im super hyped about at this price, STX is maybe good one, there are headwinds but there are tailwinds for it too, INTC maybe although very sceptical about this one but at this price, long term could be good
